Title: She's Out of My League

Length: 104 min.
Studio: DreamWorks
Director: Jim Field Smith
Writer: Sean Anders, John Morris
Starring: Jay Baruchel, Krysten Ritter, Mike Vogel, Lindsay Sloane, Alice Eve, Geoff Stults, TJ Miller, Jasika Nicole, Hayes MacArthur, Adam LeFevre, Andrew Daly, Adam Tomei, Sharon Maughan, Jessica St. Clair, Nate Torrence, Kyle Bornheimer, Kim Shaw, Brandi Engel, Joe Forgione
Rating: Not recommended for children under 7 years

Synopsis:
The twentysomething Kirk Kettner (Jay Baruchel) works as a security guard at the airport in Pittsburgh. Still going out with his colleagues at the institute and co-workers, Jack (Mike Vogel), Stainer (TJ Miller) and Devon (Nate Torrence), and dreams go out with his ex-girlfriend Marnie (Lindsay Sloane), who makes time it happened. Overall, Kirk seems content simply to keep things as they are, until the day that Molly (Alice Eve) swaggered through the security checkpoint at the airport and left forgotten the phone.

Molly is smart, sophisticated, overwhelmingly beautiful, and completely out of reach of Kirk. When Kirk returned the phone politely, she intends to thank the favor with a pair of tickets to a hockey game, and he agrees, not imagining for a second that the girl of his dreams he is proposing an appointment.

It is noted that the couple did not fit at all, a fact that both friends and family of Kirk was quick to show him. The girl is, in the words of Steiner, a "10 total", the top of the food chain of the pickups, while Kirk barely could get a five.

However, Molly is determined to conquer, and while Kirk tries to understand why a girl as beautiful may be interested in him, begins to think that maybe she sees something nobody else can see. After dinner and drinking wine with the most beautiful woman he has ever known, Kirk finally begins to believe in yourself and dream of a different future. Then causes a disastrous impression to be presented to the parents of Molly refined, and the relationship is over as quickly as it began.

With the "help" from friends, Kirk launches an offensive to recover Molly total, with hilarious results and embarrassment. With the handle of the former boyfriend of Molly and her possessive ex-girlfriend suddenly Marnie complicating things, Kirk tries to prove that, if attempted with sufficient enthusiasm, love can conquer even the most pessimistic forecasts.

Notes:
When producer Jimmy Miller, David Householter and George Gatins began work on 'Not a chance', all agreed that the success of the film at the end would depend on the real tone and maintain that the characters were believable. "We all knew what he was doing this script was unique was a combination of uninhibited humor, genuine emotion and a genuine affection for the characters," says executive producer Gatins. "We wanted to make a film with heart. If the characters are not portrayed as real people rather than as caricatures, then the public will not be emotionally involved if they can be together or not. "
